_decoded_content.title: dbt docs serve under meltano ui
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem to solve
We are using dbt for transformations but in order to see dbt docs we have to run
`meltano invoke dbt docs generate`
`meltano invoke dbt docs serve`.

We would like to include this in production env for stakeholders to see it.

### Target audience
Data Team & Stakeholders


### Further details
dbt docs served under meltano ui tab. This would make meltano ui much more useful, and also easier for teams since user management is done already.



### Proposal
Run dbt docs generate/dbt docs serve and include [catalog](https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/artifacts/catalog-json) under separate tab in meltano ui.


### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?
Meltano ui will include dbt docs!

### Regression test
(Ensure the feature doesn't cause any regressions)
- [ ] Docs get updated with every meltano invoke dbt-snowflake run

### Links / references

[dbt docs](https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/commands/cmd-docs#dbt-docs-serve)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
As a start, I think it would be good to prioritize based on:
- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

_decoded_content.title: Ability to add dbt packages in CLI without `meltano add transform ...`
_decoded_content.description:
Long-term, I'd like to replace this in sample scripts...

```
meltano add transform dbt-tap-gitlab
```

...with this...

```
meltano invoke dbt-snowflake:add-dependency --repo=https://gitlab.com/meltano/dbt-tap-gitlab
```

Then we can refer users to hub.getdbt.com for transform packages, while still having nice inline-able sample code. This won't happen in the short term though, and to keep samples working I think we have to accept `meltano add transform dbt-tap-gitlab` as sourced from the hub for a little while longer.

This also opens up a very broad range of utilities and transformation packages, both from the dbt community as well as the Meltano community. It also makes installing things like `dbt-utils` package much easier and faster for Meltano users.

Logged as feature request here: https://github.com/dbt-labs/dbt-core/issues/5302

_decoded_content.title: DBT Docs command not supported
_decoded_content.description:
### What is the current *bug* behavior?
When running the dbt docs command, we get an error stipulating that the command does not exist



### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
It should allow us to run the command

### Steps to reproduce
Run command `meltano invoke dbt:docs`


### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
Returns: `Command 'docs' could not be found. Transformer 'dbt' supports the following commands: clean, compile, deps, run, seed, snapshot, test`

### Possible fixes

Sorry, no idea

### Further regression test
_Ensure we automatically catch similar issues in the future_

- [ ] Write additional adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

_decoded_content.title: Allow `--custom` when adding transformers
_decoded_content.description:
I discovered in my dogfooding project (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meta/-/issues/234), that adding `--custom` transformers is explicitly disallowed as of now and this is problematic for the path we are going with #3298.

We should allow `transformer` plugins to be defined via `--custom` as we do today for `extractor` plugins and other types.

_decoded_content.title: Adding a Transform to a project using adapter-specific dbt installation re-adds legacy `dbt` Transformer
_decoded_content.description:
When adding a Transform plugin to a Meltano Project that already has an adapter-specific Transformer installed (e.g. `dbt-snowflake`), the legacy `dbt` transformer (and associated file bundle) are also installed, causing duplicate files in the `transform/` directory. 

![Screenshot_2022-04-01_at_16.22.04](/uploads/15966a490c53e314739f6af2246c83ef/Screenshot_2022-04-01_at_16.22.04.png)

_decoded_content.title: Duplicate files created when adding multiple transformers
_decoded_content.description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.

If you are submitting an issue with a tap, please include:

- account details
- target details
- entities selected  with meltano select (if you have selected any entities), as the bug may be related to a specific entity
- the full elt command you are running
- full output of the meltano elt command. Logs can get pretty long, so you can add the full log as a snippet in the Meltano project and add a link in the issue.
--->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

When adding a `transformer` plugin to a Meltano Project that already has a `transformer` configured, additional files are added to the Projects `/transform` directory. This is a side-effect of adapter-specific dbt `transformer` plugins sharing a single dbt project directory (and associated files, such as `dbt_project.yml`.



### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

When adding an additional `transformer` plugin, the associated file bundle should either be optional (user prompted) or omitted by default and a message displayed to invite the user to add the bundle manually (via `meltano add files dbt-snowflake`).

### Steps to reproduce

```
# add the transformer dbt
meltano add transformer dbt
# add an additional transformer
meltano add transformer dbt-snowflake
```

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screenshot_2022-04-01_at_16.22.04](/uploads/b979073394976f650fe1659b3cb16f99/Screenshot_2022-04-01_at_16.22.04.png)

![Screenshot_2022-04-01_at_16.24.47](/uploads/1802f1097d603cc5d4aad53b4c0303dd/Screenshot_2022-04-01_at_16.24.47.png)



### Possible fixes

The logic for adding related plugins (including file bundles) is directly under the CLI `add` method. Ideally this would be adapted to include logic for handling the special case of transformer file bundles.

Alternatively, transformer file bundles could be namespaced, such that adding new transformers creates a new subfolder in the `/transform` directory (e.g. `transform/dbt-snowflake/`), to avoid clashes. This approach would likely impact the migration experience of existing users.

### Further regression test
_Ensure we automatically catch similar issues in the future_

- [ ] Write additional adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

_decoded_content.title: Update dbt commands to use `--select` instead of `--models`
_decoded_content.description: Since dbt v0.21 it's recommended to use the `--select` flag instead of `--models`. https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/node-selection/syntax

_decoded_content.title: Consider a `--transformer` field for `meltano add transformer` and/or `meltano elt`
_decoded_content.description:
Following from https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3105#note_896201830, Meltano currently hardcodes the plugin name `dbt` when looking for the transformer in one or more places.

If these need to work post- #3105 , we can optionally allow the user to name their transformer.

Cc @tayloramurphy, @kgpayne

_decoded_content.title: Issue with `profiles.yml` files for `dbt` being automatically overridden during reinstall
_decoded_content.description:
As noted by @andrewstewart in [slack](https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01UW21TM98/p1647989975715829), the profiles.yml file currently is being overwritten each time the plugin is reinstalled.

We should consider changing this in our new adapter-specific versions of dbt (#3298 and #3105) so that users can be free to customize these profiles without their changes being at risk of getting overwritten.

## Workaround

As a workaround in the current state, a user can append a few lines to the end of their `dbt` "files bundle" definition:

https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/blob/master/src%2Fmeltano%2Fcore%2Fbundle%2Fdiscovery.yml#L3280-3285

```yaml
plugins:
  # ...
  files:
  - name: dbt
    # ...
    # Add these two lines to prevent reversions during reinstall:
    update:
      transform/profile/profiles.yml: false
```

_decoded_content.title: Translate dbt Dag to Orchestrator Layer
_decoded_content.description:
Related to a discussion in slack https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01UTUSP34M/p1646174917907139 where we laid out common dbt orchestration strategies.

Dagster [put out a post](https://dagster.io/blog/rebundling-the-data-platform) that translates the dbt DAG into a Dagster DAG and links it with Airbyte streams. Astronomer has [a similar post](https://www.astronomer.io/blog/airflow-dbt-1/) of how to do it in Airflow. With either tool it shouldnt be too hard to hook Meltano Singer EL jobs up to these.

Putting the debate aside of whether this is a good strategy or not, we should provide users with the tools to orchestrate dbt they way they choose.

Goal:
- Source based - Allow users to define a source or set of sources that they want to build an orchestrator DAG from. This will run the Meltano sync jobs, then all dbt DAGs that are downstream of those sources.
- Result based - Allow users to define a dbt model or set of models (fact/dim tables probably) that they want to build an orchestrator DAG from. This will run all the upstream dbt models and the Meltano sync jobs that feed them.

_decoded_content.title: dbt Selection Analysis Utilities
_decoded_content.description:
Related to a discussion in slack https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01UTUSP34M/p1646174917907139 where we laid out common dbt orchestration strategies.

A common strategy as your dbt project grows past the point of being able to just `dbt run` the whole thing is to target certain subsets of models based on their business need. Some need to be refreshed intraday vs once a week. A challenge with this strategy is that the selection criteria gets hard to manage and scary to change. Maybe we should allow dbt pipelines to be defined in Meltano in a way where we can provide useful information about this. Things like: what models are not selected by my whole list of complex selection criteria? Given the cron schedule of these model selections, are there any that are at risk of causing timing issues or collisions (i.e. if one DAG relies on a model but doesnt directly refresh it and the model is scheduled to refresh after the DAG that depends on it, indicating a stale data situation)?

These wouldnt be things in dbt itself because it requires an understanding of how/when you are scheduling models to run.

_decoded_content.title: Naming convention discussion: setting names and env vars for adapter-specific dbt plugins
_decoded_content.description:
Starting this issue to establish an agreed naming convention for adapter-specific dbt plugins.

This is targeted to unblock #3105 and (next) #3298.

For context, please review the following pair of draft MRs:

- discovery.yml representation: https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/merge_requests/2523/diffs
- files bundle (profiles.yml): https://gitlab.com/meltano/files-dbt-snowflake/-/merge_requests/2/diffs


## Consideration A: Plugin setting names

There are several common setting names which should be the same across all dbt plugins. We just need to agree what to call them, and then I think we can apply this across all dbt plugin definitions:

1. `project_dir`: `$MELTANO_PROJECT_ROOT/transform`
2. `profiles_dir`: `$MELTANO_PROJECT_ROOT/transform/profiles/snowflake`
3. `target`: E.g. `dev`, `staging`, `prod`
   - dbt users may know what 'target' means already but `target_profile_name`, `target_stage` or `target_environment` might be more explicit.
   - A best practice may emerge that this should essentially be equivalent to the `environment` name in Meltano. (`dev` Meltano environment targets `dev` dbt target profile, etc.)

These are _mostly_ going to be common/identical across adapters:

4. `database` - The default _target_ database for data transformations in dbt.
   - Other naming ideas: `database_name`, `target_db_name`, `default_db_name`
   - Note: a couple adapters call this `dbname` but I think it would be best to keep these confirmed if possible.
5. `schema` - The default _target_ schema name for data transformations in dbt.
   - Should be named in a parallel/similar manner to `db_name`, above.

Adapter-specific settings (using Snowflake as an example):

6. `account` - The snowflake account name.
   - Alternative: `account_name`
7. `user` - The snowflake user name.
8. `password` - The snowflake password.

_Decision needed: all of these _could_ be prefixed with `SF_` or `SNOWFLAKE_`. Since the adapter name is already adapter specific, I'd vote to just keep them simple and without the prefix. Without the prefixes, the config is more concise and portable, and the user doesn't need to wonder if the prefix would be `SF_` vs `SNOWFLAKE_` - or `PG_` vs `POSTGRES_` vs `POSTGRESQL_`._

### Option 1 for adapter-specific settings: simple, common setting names

With this option, we make a choice between `username` vs `user`, etc., and then we use that pattern on all adapters where applicable. Where there are setting names that only apply to one adapter, like `account` for snowflake or `iam_profile` for Redshift, we'd likely use a name that matches the dbt profile definition.

### Option 2 for adapter-specific settings: copy what the dbt adapter calls them

With this option, each dbt adapter has a different naming convention but we just copy whatever the dbt adapter has called it.

I'd like to make an exception for `database` and `schema`, since we need confidence on ability to override those programmatically across adapters. Otherwise, we could use exactly whatever setting names are asked for the dbt profile config.

## Consideration 2: Env Var names

The second consideration is regarding exactly _how_ the settings values should be passed from Meltano to dbt.

### Option 1 for env var names: use `MELTANO_TRANSFORM_<SETTING_NAME>`

I _think_ this works automatically, since `verb` matches `TRANSFORM` regardless of the transformer's plugin name.

It's nice that (I think) this works automatically, but downside is that it does feel a bit "magical".

Another nice part is that there's less to maintain on the discovery.yml level, and simply declaring the setting is enough to make the env variable available to the dbt profiles.yml file downstream.

### Option 2 for env var names: declare and pass them as (new) explicitly names env vars

In this option, the `discovery.yml` file declares settings with `env:` entries that map to a env var name which `profile` will leverage.

Initially I was in favor of this, but it creates a lot to maintain, and also the prefix is not obvious. The process of a user adding a new setting always has the risk of mismatching the names or forgetting to declare the `env:` entry.


---

## Update 2022-05-13 Documenting Decision

We decided to start with:

* `database`
* `schema`
* `account`
* `user`
* `password`

as a first pass to better map common field names.

_decoded_content.title: Adapter specific versions of Postgres, Redshift, and Bigquery
_decoded_content.description:
Follows from #3105+ 


This issue is planned as a follow-up to the initial `dbt-snowflake` release.

To have parity, we likely need these three:

- `dbt-postgres`
- `dbt-redshift`
- `dbt-bigquery`

Possible:

- `dbt-spark[PyHive]
- `dbt-presto`

Full list of dbt Labs supported adapters https://docs.getdbt.com/docs/available-adapters

_decoded_content.title: Consider defaulting `dbt_project.yml` to the root of project
_decoded_content.description:
Note: This actually would be a change in `files-dbt` (or their replacements in #3105), but logging here for visibility in the main Meltano project.

Currently, we treat dbt as if it is isolated to the `transform` subdirectory but this has some disadvantages: (1) tools that expect `.dbt` in a certain location will occasionally not be able to locate those resources, and (2) the aspects of dbt that correspond to upstream and downstream mappings (specifically source definitions and BI report or "exposure" registrations) unnaturally confined to the "transform" folder rather than being defined adjacently with the other related resources.

As teams mature and divide efforts, a "shadow folder structure" starts to appear in parallel on the two subfolders.

```
myproject
|- .meltano
|- extractors
   |- marketing
      # These get imported via meltano.yml `include_paths` feature:
      |- tap-salesforce.meltano.yml
      |- tap-pardot.meltano.yml
|- loaders
|- transform
   |- .dbt
   |- dbt_project.yml
   |- raw
      |- marketing
         # These are dbt's definition files for the respective data sources:
         |- salesforce.source.yml
         |- pardot.source.yml
   |- internal
   |- marts
      |- marketing
|- meltano.yml
```

Then, when Salesforce `select` rules are modified, for instance including a new table, the developer needs to remember to _also_ go into `transform/raw/marketing/salesforce.source.yml` and append a record for the newly included table(s).

Versus an inline, side-by-side approach:

```
myproject
|- .meltano
|- .dbt
|- sources
   |- marketing
      # The Meltano-specific and dbt-specific source definitions can coexist 
      # in the same top-level `sources` directory.
      |- tap-salesforce.meltano.yml  # <- This is the Salesforce definition for Meltano
      |- tap-salesforce.source.yml   # <- This is the Salesforce definition for dbt
      |- tap-pardot.meltano.yml
      |- tap-pardot.source.yml
|- loaders
|- transforms
   |- internal
   |- marts
      |- marketing
|- dbt_project.yml
|- meltano.yml
```

Rather than segregating the tools into subfolders per tool, the project becomes logically organized by function: "sources", "transforms", "analyses", etc. And the "analyses" folder, for instance, can contain BI reports as well as their registration information as a dbt exposure.

Note:

- Even with this change, users can still put _all_ of their definitions inside the `transforms` subdirectory, but they are not limited to _only_ having dbt resources there.
- Having meltano files side-by-side with their dbt counterparts, for instance with the `source.yml` files above alpha-sorting with and being otherwise adjacent to the meltano source definitions, allow a `CODEOWNERS` model where:
  - EL maintainers (data engineers and/or IT infosec) handle _both_ the maintenance of the Meltano EL definition and _also_ the registration of those sources in the dbt `source.yml` files.
  - Transform maintainers (generally analysts or analytic engineers) aren't necessarily code owners for source changes and source import rules.
- There's nothing technically stopping users from doing this on their existing projects, and I've done this on a prior Meltano project. It's just that by default our folder layout treats dbt as constrained to the `transforms` subfolder unless a user changes it - and users may be hesitant to do so.
- The expected location of `.dbt` is (was?) sometimes hard-coded by third party tools and expected at the root directory. It was a while back, but I ran into this issue with [VS Code Power User](https://github.com/innoverio/vscode-dbt-power-user) not finding my `.dbt` objects unless they were in the root folder. (TODO: confirm if this is still an issue in the latest versions.)

_decoded_content.title: Print plugin command text to console
_decoded_content.description:
This is based off the discussion in https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3242#note_844044166.

When running dbt we should print to the console the full command thats being executed so the user is more aware of any Meltano magic that might be happening. The example was `dbt:run` which appends `--models $DBT_MODELS` and rendered as `dbt run --models my_meltano_project` vs `dbt run` which is very similar but only renders to `dbt run`. Neither of these log anything to the console so it would be very easy to get confusing outcomes here.

Something like @aaronsteers suggested:

`Invoking dbt with 'dbt run --models my_meltano_project'...`

_decoded_content.title: Consider wrapping `dbt init` to add the appropriate profile for a given adapter
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem to solve

Creating a `profiles.yml` specific to the dbt adapter, either using the adapter's built-in (e.g. for [`dbt-postgres`](https://github.com/dbt-labs/dbt-core/blob/main/plugins/postgres/dbt/include/postgres/profile_template.yml)) or a custom `profile_template.yml` for each adapter type.

https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/commands/init

### Target audience

Users of dbt _in_ Meltano.

### Further details

`dbt init` is the standard to get started on a new dbt project or setup a personal profile for an existing one.

### Proposal

Having a profile template (for PostgreSQL)

```yaml
# transform/profile_template.yml
fixed:
  host: "{{ env_var('TARGET_POSTGRES_HOST') }}"
  port: "{{ env_var('TARGET_POSTGRES_PORT') | int }}"
  user: "{{ env_var('TARGET_POSTGRES_USER') }}"
  pass: "{{ env_var('TARGET_POSTGRES_PASSWORD') }}"
  dbname: "{{ env_var('TARGET_POSTGRES_DBNAME') }}"
  type: postgres
  schema: public
prompts: {}
```

Then running

```console
$ meltano invoke dbt init
19:30:52  Running with dbt=1.0.1
19:30:52  Setting up your profile.
19:30:52  Profile meltano written to /Users/edgarramirez/projects/try-dbt-init/transform/profile/profiles.yml using project's profile_template.yml and your supplied values. Run 'dbt debug' to validate the connection.
```

results in the following

```yaml
# transform/profile/profiles.yml
meltano:
  outputs:
    dev:
      dbname: '{{ env_var(''TARGET_POSTGRES_DBNAME'') }}'
      host: '{{ env_var(''TARGET_POSTGRES_HOST'') }}'
      pass: '{{ env_var(''TARGET_POSTGRES_PASSWORD'') }}'
      port: '{{ env_var(''TARGET_POSTGRES_PORT'') | int }}'
      schema: public
      type: postgres
      user: '{{ env_var(''TARGET_POSTGRES_USER'') }}'
  target: dev
```

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Starting and configuring a dbt project with Meltano is smoother.

### Regression test
(Ensure the feature doesn't cause any regressions)
- [ ] Write adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

### Links / references

_Please note that this was taken from GitLab, to be changed accordingly_

_decoded_content.title: Meltano Test bug with files bundles
_decoded_content.description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.

If you are submitting an issue with a tap, please include:

- account details
- target details
- entities selected  with meltano select (if you have selected any entities), as the bug may be related to a specific entity
- the full elt command you are running
- full output of the meltano elt command. Logs can get pretty long, so you can add the full log as a snippet in the Meltano project and add a link in the issue.
--->

This is based on [this slack thread](https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C013EKWA2Q1/p1643388924407829).

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
_What is happening now?_

When I try to use the `test` feature with dbt I get a message saying:
`Command 'test_publish_hub' could not be found. File bundle 'dbt' does not define any commands.`. It looks like its iterating my plugins by name and getting to my file bundle named `dbt` before it gets to my transformer named `dbt`. If I remove the files bundle, my tests work. If I rename my files bundle I get errors.

```
  transformers:
  - name: dbt
    pip_url: git+https://github.com/Tomme/dbt-athena.git@c8e0458f85aaa8f9b693f99903ba95c41b90573b
    config:
      target: athena
    commands:
      test_publish_hub: test --models marts.publish.meltano_hub.*
  files:
  - name: dbt
    pip_url: git+https://gitlab.com/meltano/files-dbt.git@config-version-2
```

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
_What should be happening?_

The test feature shouldnt consider tests in the files plugin section. Maybe larger than that it might need to accept a plugin.plugin_name combo (i.e. meltano test transformer.dbt:test_123) if a project has multiple plugins with the same name.

### Steps to reproduce
_How one can reproduce the issue?_

Install dbt then add a command starting with the test prefix and run `meltano test dbt:test_name`.


### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
_Please use code blocks (\`\`\`) to format console output_



### Possible fixes
_If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem or suggest a fix_



### Further regression test
_Ensure we automatically catch similar issues in the future_

- [ ] Write additional adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

_decoded_content.title: Use dbt 1.x.x
_decoded_content.description: Use dbt 1.0 as Meltano will start supporting it via https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3176

_decoded_content.title: Support dbt>=1.0.0
_decoded_content.description:
In [dbt `1.0.0`](https://github.com/dbt-labs/dbt-core/releases/tag/v1.0.0):

> - Change the default dbt packages installation directory to `dbt_packages` from `dbt_modules`. Also rename `modules-path` to `packages-install-path` to allow default overrides of package install directory. Deprecation warning added for projects using the old `dbt_modules` name without specifying a `packages-install-path`. (#3523)
> 
> - Marked `source-paths` and `data-paths` as deprecated keys in `dbt_project.yml` in favor of `model-paths` and `seed-paths` respectively.

- [ ] `source-paths` => `model-paths`
- [ ] `data-paths` => `seed-paths`
- [ ] `dbt_modules` => `dbt_packages`
- [ ] `modules-path` => `packages-install-path`
- [ ] Require dbt>=1.0.0 (https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/project-configs/require-dbt-version)

https://docs.getdbt.com/docs/guides/migration-guide/upgrading-to-1-0-0

_decoded_content.title: Support dbt>=1.0.0
_decoded_content.description:
In [dbt `1.0.0`](https://github.com/dbt-labs/dbt-core/releases/tag/v1.0.0):

> - Change the default dbt packages installation directory to `dbt_packages` from `dbt_modules`. Also rename `modules-path` to `packages-install-path` to allow default overrides of package install directory. Deprecation warning added for projects using the old `dbt_modules` name without specifying a `packages-install-path`. (#3523)
> 
> - Marked `source-paths` and `data-paths` as deprecated keys in `dbt_project.yml` in favor of `model-paths` and `seed-paths` respectively.

- [ ] `source-paths` => `model-paths`
- [ ] `data-paths` => `seed-paths`
- [ ] `dbt_modules` => `dbt_packages`
- [ ] `modules-path` => `packages-install-path`
- [ ] Require dbt>=1.0.0 (https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/project-configs/require-dbt-version)

https://docs.getdbt.com/docs/guides/migration-guide/upgrading-to-1-0-0
